image.altText: Complex of grey buildings behind a fence

props.synopsis: Tasmania's prison service operated a "hostile management regime" within a high security unit at Risdon Prison, Tasmania's Custodial Inspector has revealed.

title.children: Teenage inmate exposes 'unsanctioned' punishment regime in Tasmanian prison

image.altText: A dimly lit pokies room with bright colourful lights coming from each of the machines.

props.synopsis: Former treasurer Michael Ferguson was one of the cashless card's biggest advocates within the government. Now that he's resigned from cabinet, there are fears the government won't stick to its policy announced two years ago.

title.children: Is the Tasmanian government still committed to a cashless gaming card without Michael Ferguson in cabinet?

image.altText: Paula Wriedt stands in front of an oval holding a large concept plan

props.synopsis: When Paula Wriedt was elected to the Tasmanian parliament in 1996, a radio interviewer was more interested in her smile than her policies. Cr Wriedt, now a local government mayor, is hopeful the situation for women in politics is improving.

title.children: It can be tough being a woman in politics, but former MP Paula Wriedt says she's enjoying being back in public life

image.altText: A woman in pink pants crouching next to a preserved Tasmanian Tiger.

props.synopsis: The team behind a bid to 'de-extinct' the Tasmanian tiger says it has made significant breakthroughs, including producing a genome that is 99.9-per-cent accurate. Scientists say the scientific progress is welcome but they want to see the data.

title.children: Tasmanian tiger 'de-extinction' project claims genome breakthrough â€” but other scientists want to see the data

image.altText: looking for modi podcast

props.synopsis:
Tasmania has more women in state parliament than men and we're the first Australian state to do so.

A new program encouraging even more women to enter the fray has just wrapped up with 11 graduates across the age and political spectrum getting a taste of what to expect.Â 

Bagging politicians is practically a national sport, but do female pollies cop it more than men?

It was a pretty rough ride for some of the trailblazers and although things have changed in recent years ... by how much?

Featuring Fiona Blackwood.Â

title.children: TASSIECAST: Have things changed for women in politics?

image.altText: A graphic image of a curved three-storey building on a waterfront

props.synopsis: A Tasmanian hotel development locked in a Supreme Court dispute over whether the local council has the right to buy back the land it will be built on will bypass council planning laws to be assessed as a major infrastructure project.
